question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Gourav was n̲o̲ ̲g̲o̲o̲d̲ than a foolish person.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 12-Sep Shift 1)
solution:
Correct Answer: no better

Explanation: The correct phrase is "no better than" when comparing two things.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Arushya purchased t̲h̲e̲ ̲m̲o̲s̲t̲ ̲g̲o̲o̲d̲ of all the suits kept in the shop.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 24-Sep Shift 3)
solution:
Correct Answer:the best

Explanation:

  • "Most good" is grammatically incorrect because "good" has an irregular comparative and superlative form: good → better → best.

  • "The best" is the correct superlative form to indicate the highest quality among all suits.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
The chair I have bought recently i̲s̲ ̲c̲o̲s̲t̲l̲y̲ than what I bought last year.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 26-Sep Shift 1)
solution:
Correct Answer: is costlier
Explanation: The sentence is comparing the cost of two chairs, so the correct form is "is costlier," which is the comparative form of "costly."
Other options:

  • will be costly: Incorrect, as the sentence is in the present tense.

  • is the costliest: Incorrect, as this implies the chair is the most expensive, which isn't what the sentence intends.

  • was costly: Incorrect, as it would refer to the past, but the sentence is talking about a present comparison.

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Ashoka was the greatest t̲h̲a̲n̲ ̲a̲l̲l̲ ̲t̲h̲e̲ ̲M̲a̲u̲r̲y̲a̲n̲ ̲E̲m̲p̲e̲r̲o̲r̲s̲ .

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 25-Sep Shift 2)
option_2: to all another Mauryan Emperors
solution:
Correct Answer:"of the Mauryan Emperors"

Explanation:
The sentence is comparing Ashoka with all Mauryan Emperors, which requires the superlative form ("the greatest of"). The correct structure for superlative comparisons is "the greatest of", not "the greatest than."

Other options:

  • "to other Mauryan Emperors" –as "to" is not used for superlative comparisons.

  • "to all another Mauryan Emperors" –, as "another" is singular, whereas "Emperors" is plural.

  • "allMauryan Emperors" –as it lacks the correct superlative structure.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
This book g̲i̲v̲i̲n̲g̲ ̲u̲s̲ ̲m̲u̲c̲h̲ ̲i̲n̲f̲o̲r̲m̲a̲t̲i̲o̲n̲ about our freedom fighters who lost their lives while serving our motherland.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 23-Sep Shift 1)
solution:
Correct Answer:gives us much information

Explanation: The singular verb "gives" is required because the subject "This book" is singular. The noun "information" is uncountable, so "much" is the correct quantifier instead of "many."

Other options:

  • "give us many information": as "give" is used with plural subjects, and "many" is incorrect for the uncountable noun "information."

  • "gives us many information": as "many" is not used with uncountable nouns like "information."

  • "give us much information": as "give" does not agree with the singular subject "This book."

question:
Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence.
He was the m̲o̲s̲t̲ ̲c̲l̲e̲v̲e̲r̲e̲s̲t̲ man I ever knew.

(SSC Steno 2024 T-1 : 10 Dec Shift-1)
solution:
Correct Answer: cleverest

Explanation:

The correct sentence should be "He was the cleverest man I ever knew." This is because "cleverest" is the superlative form of the adjective "clever," which is used to describe the most clever person or thing in comparison to others.

question:
Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence. In case no improvement is needed, select ‘No improvement required’.
Shimla is t̲h̲e̲ ̲m̲o̲r̲e̲ ̲b̲e̲a̲u̲t̲i̲f̲u̲l̲ hill station in Himachal Pradesh.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-2 (8 Mar))
solution:
The underlined phrase "the more beautiful" is incorrect because it implies a comparison, but no other hill station is mentioned for comparison.

Let’s examine each option:

  • Option 1: "the very beautiful" – grammatically awkward and not commonly used in standard English to describe a general place.

  • Option 2: "a very beautiful" – correct. It indicates that Shimla is one of the many beautiful hill stations, without comparing.

  • Option 3: "a more beautiful" – implies a comparison, but no comparison is present in the sentence.

  • Option 4: "No improvement required" – incorrect because the original phrase is ungrammatical.

Correct choice:a very beautiful

question:
Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence. In case no improvement is needed, select ‘No improvement required’.
M̲i̲n̲e̲ ̲g̲r̲a̲n̲d̲m̲o̲t̲h̲e̲r̲ ̲n̲e̲e̲d̲ a helper to keep her terrace garden in order.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-2 (8 Mar))
solution:
Explanation:

  • "Mine" is an archaic or poetic form used without a noun (e.g., This book is mine). It cannot be used directly before a noun like “grandmother”.

  • The correct possessive determiner before a noun is "my" (e.g., My grandmother).

  • "Needs" is correct here (present simple) to match the subject "grandmother" (singular).

Correct sentence:My grandmother needs a helper to keep her terrace garden in order.

question:
Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence. In case no improvement is needed, select ‘No improvement required’.
People with Alzheimer are s̲u̲c̲h̲ ̲f̲o̲r̲g̲e̲t̲t̲i̲n̲g̲ ̲a̲s̲ they are not able to carry out a conversation for long.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-2 (30 April))
solution:
Explanation:

The sentence requires a structure that connects cause and effect. The correct idiomatic expression is:

  • "so + adjective + that"

Here:

  • "so forgetful that" is correct.

  • "forgetful" is the correct adjective form to describe a person who forgets things easily.

  • "forgetting" is the present participle/verb form, which is incorrect in this context.

Corrected Sentence:

People with Alzheimer are so forgetful that they are not able to carry out a conversation for long.

question:
Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence. In case no improvement is needed, select ‘No improvement required’.
The Trans-Siberian Railway in Russia is t̲h̲e̲ ̲f̲a̲s̲t̲e̲r̲ ̲railway line in the world.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-2 (30 April))
solution:
Solution:

  • The phrase "the faster railway line" is incorrect because it uses the comparative degree ("faster") instead of the superlative degree ("fastest") which is required when comparing more than two or indicating the topmost degree.

  • The correct usage here is: "the fastest railway line in the world."

Correct Sentence:
The Trans-Siberian Railway in Russia is the fastest railway line in the world.

question:
Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence. In case no improvement is needed, select ‘No improvement required’.
She can speak fluently in French, German and Italian; h̲e̲r̲ ̲l̲i̲n̲g̲u̲i̲s̲t̲i̲c̲ ̲s̲k̲i̲l̲l̲s̲ ̲a̲r̲e̲ ̲i̲m̲p̲r̲e̲s̲s̲i̲n̲g̲.̲

(SSC CPO 2024 T-2 (30 April))
option_1: her linguistical skills are impressing
option_2: her linguistic skills are impressive
option_3: her linguistic skills are impressed
solution:
Solution:

  • The sentence refers to her ability to speak multiple languages, which relates to linguistic skills.

  • The phrase "are impressing" is grammatically incorrect here.

  • The correct adjective to use is "impressive", which describes something that evokes admiration.

Correct Sentence:
She can speak fluently in French, German and Italian; her linguistic skills are impressive.

Correct Option:
(2) her linguistic skills are impressive

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
T̲h̲i̲s̲ ̲i̲s̲ ̲b̲e̲s̲t̲ ̲b̲o̲o̲k̲ for children to read.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (01-July Shift 1))
option_2: This is very good book
option_3: This is the best book
option_4: This is very best book
solution:
The most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment "best book" is:

This is the best book.

So the sentence would read:
"This is the best book for children to read."

Here's why:

  • "This is the best book" is grammatically correct and makes sense when referring to a specific book as the best option.

  • The other options are incorrect:

  • "This is good book" is missing the article "a" before "good."

  • "This is very good book" also lacks the article "a" and is awkward because "very good" is less appropriate in this context than "the best."

  • "This is very best book" is incorrect because "very best" is not grammatically correct. "Best" is already a superlative, so "very" is redundant.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Mahima is a̲s̲ ̲s̲m̲a̲r̲t̲e̲r̲ ̲a̲s̲ Shilpi.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (09-July Shift 3))
solution:
Correct Answer: as smart as

Explanation:
The correct comparative structure for equality is "as + adjective + as."

Let’s evaluate the options:

  • most smart as – Incorrect; "most" is used for superlatives, not comparisons of equality.

  • as smart as – ✅ Correct; standard structure for equal comparison.

  • more smart as – Incorrect; "more" is used with "than," not "as."

  • smartest than – Incorrect; superlative with "than" is wrong.

So, the correct sentence is:
"Mahima is as smart as Shilpi."

question:
Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence. In case no improvement is needed, select No improvement required.
Although uncountable files stack up on the tables of government officials, they prefer doing their work a̲t̲ ̲a̲ ̲m̲o̲r̲e̲ ̲l̲e̲i̲s̲u̲r̲e̲ ̲p̲a̲c̲e̲.̲

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (10-July Shift 1))
option_1: at a more leisurely paced
option_2: at a more leisurely pace
option_3: at a more leisure paced
solution:
Correct Answer: at a more leisurely pace

Explanation:
The phrase "leisure pace" is incorrect because "leisure" is a noun and cannot directly describe "pace". The correct adjective form is "leisurely", which means unhurried or relaxed.

Let’s evaluate the options:

  • at a more leisurely paced – ❌ Incorrect; "paced" is an adjective but does not fit after "a more" and before "pace".

  • at a more leisurely pace – ✅ Correct; grammatically sound and idiomatically appropriate.

  • at a more leisure paced – ❌ Incorrect; "leisure" cannot be used as an adjective this way.

  • No improvement needed – ❌ Incorrect; improvement is clearly required.

Correct sentence:
"Although uncountable files stack up on the tables of government officials, they prefer doing their work at a more leisurely pace."

question:
Change the following sentence into positive degree.
Yash is not better than Harsh.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.11_08-Oct_Shift-3)
option_1: Yash is best than Harsh.
option_2: Yash is as good as Harsh.
option_3: Yash and Harsh both are good.
option_4: Yash is not good than Harsh.
solution:
Correct answer: Yash is as good as Harsh.

Explanation:

  • The sentence "Yash is not better than Harsh" means both have equal ability or quality.

  • The positive degree to express equality is "Yash is as good as Harsh."

  • Other options:

  • Yash is best than Harsh – incorrect comparative and superlative usage

  • Yash and Harsh both are good – correct in meaning but less direct

  • Yash is not good than Harsh – grammatically incorrect

Correct sentence:
"Yash is as good as Harsh."

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no need to substitute it, select ‘No substitution’.
Commodity prices are the d̲e̲a̲r̲e̲r̲ in the present economic scenario.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.17_14-Oct_Shift-3)
solution:
Correct Answer:dearest

Explanation:

  • The sentence is making a superlative comparison (i.e., comparing prices to all others in the present scenario).

  • The correct superlative form of "dear" (which can mean expensive) is "dearest".

  • ✅ "Commodity prices are the dearest in the present economic scenario."

Let’s review the options:

  • No substitution – incorrect because "dearer" is the comparative form, not the superlative.

  • Dear – base form; incorrect.

  • Quite dear – not a comparison; just an intensifier.

Therefore, the correct replacement is dearest.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Dolphins are named among the i̲n̲t̲e̲l̲l̲i̲g̲e̲n̲t̲ animals on earth.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.19_15-Oct_Shift-2)
solution:
Correct Answer: most intelligent

Explanation:
The sentence refers to dolphins being one of the smartest animals, which requires the superlative form of the adjective "intelligent".

Correct sentence: Dolphins are named among the most intelligent animals on earth.

Other options:
intelligentest – incorrect and non-standard ❌
more intelligent – comparative, used when comparing two things ❌
intelligenter – incorrect form ❌

Only most intelligent is grammatically correct and contextually appropriate.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined words in the given sentence.
In the beauty contest, Parul won the award for being the b̲e̲a̲u̲t̲i̲f̲u̲l̲ one.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.19_15-Oct_Shift-2)
solution:
Correct Answer: most beautiful

Explanation:
The sentence talks about winning an award in a beauty contest, implying Parul was judged the best among all. This requires the superlative form — "most beautiful".

Correct sentence: In the beauty contest, Parul won the award for being the most beautiful one.

Other options:
least beautiful – opposite of what the sentence means ❌
less beautiful – comparative, used between two ❌
more beautiful – comparative, not suitable when referring to the best overall ❌

Only most beautiful fits both the grammar and context.

question:
Change the following sentence into positive degree.
Mercury is the smallest planet in the solar system.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.19_15-Oct_Shift-2)
option_1: Mercury is smaller than any other planet in the solar system.
option_2: Mercury is the smallest planet than any other one.
option_3: The most smallest planet in the solar system is mercury.
option_4: No other planet is as small as Mercury in the Solar System.
solution:
Correct Answer: No other planet is as small as Mercury in the Solar System.

Explanation:
To change a sentence from superlative degree (the smallest) to positive degree, we use the structure:
No other [noun] is as [positive form of adjective] as [subject].

Original: Mercury is the smallest planet in the solar system.
Positive degree: No other planet is as small as Mercury in the Solar System.

Other options are grammatically incorrect or not in positive degree.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
We have perhaps never seen an a̲b̲l̲e̲s̲t̲ series of advocates than these ten standing in a row.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.20_15-Oct_Shift-3)
solution:
Correct Answer: abler

Explanation:
The sentence uses "than", which indicates a comparison. In such cases, we use the comparative form of the adjective — not the superlative.

  • "Abler" is the correct comparative form of "able".

  • "Ablest" is the superlative form, used when comparing one against all others, not when using "than".

Correct sentence: We have perhaps never seen abler series of advocates than these ten standing in a row.

Other options:
the ablest – incorrect due to the use of "than" ❌
most ablest – grammatically incorrect (double superlative) ❌
more able – awkward and less natural than "abler" ❌

So, "abler" is the most appropriate substitution.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
The questions in part B looks d̲i̲f̲f̲i̲c̲u̲l̲t̲ than the questions in part A.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.20_15-Oct_Shift-3)
solution:
Correct Answer: more difficult

Explanation:
The sentence is making a comparison between two things: questions in part B and questions in part A.
For comparisons between two, we use the comparative form of the adjective — and the correct comparative form of "difficult" is "more difficult".

Correct sentence: The questions in part B look more difficult than the questions in part A.

Other options:
difficultier – incorrect; not a real word ❌
difficultly – adverb; not suitable here ❌
most difficult – superlative; used when comparing more than two ❌

Only more difficult fits grammatically and contextually.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
He is the h̲e̲a̲l̲t̲h̲y̲ person I have ever met in life.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.21_16-Oct_Shift-1)
solution:
Correct Answer: healthiest

Explanation:
The sentence implies a superlative degree — comparing one person against all others the speaker has met.

  • The correct superlative form of "healthy" is "healthiest".

  • It is also preceded by "the", which confirms the need for the superlative.

Correct sentence: He is the healthiest person I have ever met in life.

Other options:
most healthy – grammatically acceptable but less natural than “healthiest” ❌
healthier / more healthy – comparative, used when comparing two people ❌

✅ healthiest is the most appropriate and natural choice.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Osmium is h̲e̲a̲v̲y̲ metal in the periodic table.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.22_16-Oct_Shift-2)
solution:
Answer: the heaviest

Explanation:
The sentence talks about Osmium being the most extreme in weight compared to all other metals. In such cases, we use the superlative form.

  • Heaviest is the superlative of heavy, used when comparing one with all others.
    (Hindi: सबसे भारी)

Let’s check the options:

  • the heaviest – ✅ Correct superlative form

  • the most heavy – ❌ Incorrect; "heavy" forms its superlative as "heaviest," not "most heavy"

  • more heavy – ❌ Comparative form, not superlative

  • heavier – ❌ Comparative form, used between two items only

Correct sentence:
"Osmium is the heaviest metal in the periodic table."

question:
Select the appropriate option that can substitute the underlined word in the following sentence to make it grammatically correct.
Only t̲h̲e̲ ̲b̲e̲a̲u̲t̲i̲f̲u̲l̲ painting is to be displayed in the exhibition.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.23_16-Oct_Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: the most beautiful

Explanation:
The sentence refers to only one painting being selected for display, implying a superlative choice among many.

  • "The most beautiful" is the superlative form of "beautiful" and is used when comparing three or more items and choosing the one with the highest degree of the quality.
    (Hindi: सबसे सुंदर) – ✅ Correct usage

Let’s review the other options:

  • the much beautiful – ❌ Incorrect; “much” is not used this way with adjectives

  • more beautiful – ❌ Comparative, used for comparing two things

  • beautiful – ❌ Missing the superlative emphasis required by "only"

Correct sentence:
"Only the most beautiful painting is to be displayed in the exhibition."

question:
Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence.
The bishop sadly declared that the poor gentleman who was dead was q̲u̲i̲e̲t̲e̲r̲ of the community.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.25_17-Oct_Shift-2)
solution:
Answer: the quietest

Explanation:
The sentence is comparing the gentleman to others in the community, so the superlative form of "quiet" is needed.

  • The quietest is the superlative form used when comparing one person against all others in a group.
    (Hindi: सबसे शांत) – ✅ Correct choice

Other options:

  • Most quiet – grammatically incorrect for "quiet"; superlative is "quietest"

  • Quiet – positive form, no comparison

  • The quieter – comparative form, used between two, not suitable here

Correct sentence:
"The bishop sadly declared that the poor gentleman who was dead was the quietest of the community."

question:
Correct the underlined part of the sentence.
This mango is b̲i̲t̲t̲e̲r̲e̲r̲.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.26_17-Oct_Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: bitter

Explanation:
The word "bitterer" is incorrect because "bitter" is a short adjective that forms its comparative by adding "-er" (bitter → bitterer), but "bitter" is commonly considered a two-syllable adjective that often uses "more bitter" for comparison in formal English.

However, in most contexts, "bitter" is used without "er" or "more" when simply describing taste. Since the sentence likely intends to say the mango is bitter, not comparing it, the correct form is:

  • bitter (positive form)

Other options:

  • bitterest – superlative (most bitter)

  • more bitter – comparative form, correct but not needed here

  • most bitter – superlative

Correct sentence:
"This mango is bitter."

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
He possesses one of the s̲l̲i̲m̲m̲e̲r̲ handsets in the world.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.27_18-Oct_Shift-1)
solution:
Answer: slimmest

Explanation:
The sentence is:
"He possesses one of the s̲l̲i̲m̲m̲e̲r̲ handsets in the world."

  • When comparing one item among many in the highest degree, we use the superlative form of the adjective.

  • The correct superlative form of "slim" is "slimmest."

  • The phrase "one of the slimmest" correctly indicates that the handset is among the thinnest.

Other options:

  • most slim – incorrect because "slim" forms superlative by adding "-mest," not by "most"

  • slim – positive form, not comparative or superlative

  • most slimmest – incorrect double superlative

Correct sentence:
"He possesses one of the slimmest handsets in the world."

question:
Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence. In case no improvement is needed, select 'No improvement required'.
He received the best employee award because he was the m̲o̲r̲e̲ ̲h̲a̲r̲d̲w̲o̲r̲k̲i̲n̲g̲.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.27_18-Oct_Shift-1)
solution:
Answer: most hardworking

Explanation:
The sentence is:
"He received the best employee award because he was the m̲o̲r̲e̲ ̲h̲a̲r̲d̲w̲o̲r̲k̲i̲n̲g̲."

  • When comparing one person as the top in a group, we use the superlative form of the adjective.

  • "Hardworking" is a two-syllable adjective that commonly forms the superlative with "most" rather than "-est".

  • The correct superlative form is "most hardworking."

Other options:

  • The hardworking – incorrect without a superlative or comparative structure

  • Hardworking – positive form, no comparison

  • No improvement required – incorrect, as "more hardworking" is wrong here

Correct sentence:
"He received the best employee award because he was the most hardworking."

question:
Select the correct option of the given sentence.
Smt. Savithri is wisest than all others in the group.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.27_18-Oct_Shift-1)
option_1: Smt. Savithri is the wise than all others in the group.
option_2: Smt. Savithri is wise than all others in the group.
option_3: Smt. Savithri is wiser than all others in the group.
option_4: Smt. Savithri is the wiser than all others in the group.
solution:
Answer: Smt. Savithri is wiser than all others in the group.

Explanation:
When comparing two or more things, the comparative form "wiser" is used with "than."

  • Wiser is the correct comparative form of wise for comparing.

  • The superlative form is "wisest", which is used with "the" when comparing one among many.

Correct sentence:
"Smt. Savithri is wiser than all others in the group."

Other options are grammatically incorrect.

question:
Select the grammatically correct sentence.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.28_18-Oct_Shift-2)
option_1: Rahul is very naughty as he is the youngest sibling between Rama’s three brothers.
option_2: Rahul is very naughty as he is the most young sibling between Rama’s three brothers.
option_3: Rahul is very naughty as he is the youngest sibling among Rama’s three brothers.
option_4: Rahul is very naughty as he is the most young sibling among Rama’s three brothers.
solution:
Answer: Rahul is very naughty as he is the youngest sibling among Rama’s three brothers.

Explanation:

  • The correct comparative form is "youngest" (superlative of "young").

  • When referring to a group, we use "among" (for more than two) instead of "between" (usually for two).

  • "Most young" is incorrect; use "youngest."

Correct sentence:
"Rahul is very naughty as he is the youngest sibling among Rama’s three brothers."

question:
Select the most appropriate form of comparative degree that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Rohit Sharma i̲s̲ ̲b̲e̲t̲t̲e̲r̲ ̲t̲h̲a̲n̲ ̲m̲o̲r̲e̲ ̲o̲t̲h̲e̲r̲ ̲b̲a̲t̲s̲m̲a̲n̲ in the world.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.28_18-Oct_Shift-2)
option_2: as good as the most other batsmen
option_4: better than most other batsmen
solution:
Answer: better than most other batsmen

Explanation:
The sentence:
"Rohit Sharma is better than more other batsman in the world."

  • The correct comparative form is "better than most other batsmen."

  • "More other" is incorrect; "most other" or "most of the other" is used.

  • "Batsmen" is plural.

Other options:

  • Better batsmen – incomplete phrase

  • As good as the most other batsmen – awkward and incorrect

  • The best batsmen – superlative, not comparative

Correct sentence:
"Rohit Sharma is better than most other batsmen in the world."

question:
Select the option that changes the degree of comparison in the given sentence from superlative to positive without changing the meaning of the sentence.
Kalpana Ahuja is the tallest girl in the colony.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.29_18-Oct_Shift-3)
option_1: Kalpana Ahuja is as tallest as other girls of the colony.
option_2: Many girls in the colony are taller than Kalpana Ahuja.
option_3: No other girl in the colony is as tall as Kalpana Ahuja.
option_4: No other girl in the colony is as taller as Kalpana Ahuja.
solution:
Answer: No other girl in the colony is as tall as Kalpana Ahuja.

Explanation:

  • The original sentence uses the superlative form: "the tallest girl."

  • The correct positive degree form that keeps the same meaning is:
    "No other girl in the colony is as tall as Kalpana Ahuja."

  • This compares Kalpana’s height with others without using the superlative.

Other options:

  • "Kalpana Ahuja is as tallest as other girls" – incorrect grammar

  • "Many girls in the colony are taller than Kalpana Ahuja" – opposite meaning

  • "No other girl in the colony is as taller as Kalpana Ahuja" – incorrect grammar

Correct sentence:
"No other girl in the colony is as tall as Kalpana Ahuja."

question:
Change the following sentence into positive degree.
Ramesh is not stronger than Mahesh.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.29_18-Oct_Shift-3)
option_1: Ramesh is as strong than Mahesh.
option_2: Mahesh is strongest than Ramesh.
option_3: Mahesh is as strong as Ramesh.
option_4: Mahesh is stronger than Ramesh.
solution:
Answer: Mahesh is as strong as Ramesh.

Explanation:
The sentence "Ramesh is not stronger than Mahesh" means both are equal in strength or Mahesh is at least as strong as Ramesh.

  • The positive degree equivalent is:
    "Mahesh is as strong as Ramesh."

Other options are incorrect because:

  • "Ramesh is as strong than Mahesh." – incorrect grammar

  • "Mahesh is strongest than Ramesh." – incorrect comparative form

  • "Mahesh is stronger than Ramesh." – opposite meaning

Correct sentence:
"Mahesh is as strong as Ramesh."

question:
Select the most appropriate form of comparative degree that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Neha’s house is f̲a̲r̲ ̲f̲r̲o̲m̲ ̲t̲h̲e̲ ̲c̲i̲t̲y̲ ̲t̲h̲a̲n̲ everyone else’s.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.29_18-Oct_Shift-3)
option_1: more far from the city to
option_2: further from the city than
option_3: farther from the city than
option_4: far from the city to
solution:
Answer: farther from the city than

Explanation:
The sentence is:
"Neha’s house is far from the city than everyone else’s."

  • For physical distances, "farther" is the correct comparative form.

  • It should be followed by "than" to compare.

Other options:

  • More far from the city to – incorrect structure

  • Further from the city than – "further" is generally for metaphorical distances; "farther" is preferred for physical distances

  • Far from the city to – incorrect structure

Correct sentence:
"Neha’s house is farther from the city than everyone else’s."

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined word in the given sentence.
Mita is s̲m̲a̲r̲t̲ than many other kids in the school.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.3_30-Sep_Shift-3)
solution:
Correct answer:smarter

Explanation:

The sentence is: "Mita is ___ than many other kids in the school."
This sentence involves a comparison between two entities: Mita and other kids.

  • When comparing two things or people, we use the comparative degree of adjectives.

  • The correct comparative form of "smart" is "smarter."

Let’s evaluate the options:

  • Smarter – comparative form of “smart” → ✅ correct

  • Less smart – also comparative, but suggests inferiority, which changes the meaning

  • Most smart – incorrect form; the correct superlative is smartest

  • Smartest – superlative form, used when comparing more than two or showing the highest degree → not suitable here

Hence, smarter is the correct substitution for the underlined word.

question:
Change the following sentence into positive degree.
Sushma is one of the smartest girls in the class.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.31_21-Oct_Shift-2)
option_1: Sushma is smarter than any other girls in the class.
option_2: Sushma is the smart girl of the class.
option_3: Few girls in the class are as smart as Sushma.
option_4: No other girl is as smart as Sushma.
solution:
Answer: Few girls in the class are as smart as Sushma.

Explanation:

  • The positive degree expresses equality without using comparative or superlative forms.

  • "Few girls in the class are as smart as Sushma" means that only a small number of girls have the same level of intelligence as Sushma, which is a way of stating equality in positive degree.

Other options:

  • Sushma is smarter than any other girls – Comparative, not positive.

  • Sushma is the smart girl – Incorrect article usage, should be "the smartest."

  • No other girl is as smart as Sushma – Also positive degree but option 3 better fits the context of positive degree expressing limited equality.

Correct positive degree sentence:
"Few girls in the class are as smart as Sushma."

question:
Select the sentence with the most appropriate Superlative degree.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.33_22-Oct_Shift-1)
option_1: She is the talentedest musician in the orchestra.
option_2: She is the talent of all musicians in the orchestra.
option_3: She is the most talented musician in the orchestra.
option_4: She is more talented musician in the orchestra.
solution:
Answer: She is the most talented musician in the orchestra.

Explanation:
When comparing qualities in a group, the superlative degree is used to show the highest level of that quality.

  • "Most talented" is the correct superlative form of "talented."

  • "Talentedest" is incorrect because superlatives for adjectives with three or more syllables are formed with "most," not by adding "-est."

  • "She is the talent of all musicians" is incorrect and does not use comparative or superlative forms properly.

  • "She is more talented musician" is incorrect because "more talented" needs "a" or "the" before "musician" (e.g., "a more talented musician").

Therefore, the correct sentence is:
"She is the most talented musician in the orchestra."

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no need to substitute it, select ‘No substitution required’.
Everyone in the room was in a̲ ̲j̲o̲l̲l̲y̲ and relaxed mood.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.34_22-Oct_Shift-2)
solution:
Answer: No substitution required

Explanation:
The sentence is:
"Everyone in the room was in a jolly and relaxed mood."

Here, "jolly" is correctly used as an adjective describing the mood. It is not a comparison, so the comparative form "jollier" is not needed. The sentence simply states the mood was cheerful and relaxed.

  • Using "jollier" would imply a comparison, which the sentence does not indicate.

  • "Most jolly" or "more jollier" are incorrect for the same reason.

Hence, no substitution is required.

question:
Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence.
Indeed, Jack is one of t̲h̲e̲ ̲c̲l̲e̲v̲e̲r̲ men I have ever met.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.35_22-Oct_Shift-3)
solution:
Answer:the cleverest

Explanation:
The phrase "one of the..." should be followed by a superlative degree of the adjective when comparing among many.
So, the correct form is "one of the cleverest men" (सबसे चतुर व्यक्तियों में से एक).

Correct sentence:
Indeed, Jack is one of the cleverest men I have ever met.

Other options:

  • cleverer – comparative degree (comparisons between two), not suitable here

  • clever – positive degree, incorrect with "one of the"

  • most clever – grammatically acceptable but "the cleverest" is more idiomatic and preferred

question:
Select the grammatically correct sentence from the given options.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.37_23-Oct_Shift-2)
option_1: The Nile is the long river in the world with a length about approximately 6650 km.
option_2: The Nile is the longest river in the world with a length of approximately 6650 km.
option_3: The Nile is the most long river in the world of a length of approximately 6650 km.
option_4: The Nile is the longest river in the world with a length about approximately 6650 km.
solution:
Answer:The Nile is the longest river in the world with a length of approximately 6650 km.

Explanation:
This sentence is grammatically correct and clear in meaning. Let’s break it down:

  • "The longest river" is the correct superlative form of "long" (not "long" or "most long").

  • "with a length of approximately" is the correct phrase. We use "of" after "length", not "about".

  • "approximately" already means "about", so using both is redundant.

Now, why the others are incorrect:

  • "The Nile is the long river..." – ❌ incorrect; should be "longest" for superlative.

  • "most long" – ❌ not used; use "longest" instead.

  • "about approximately" – ❌ redundant; use only one.

Correct sentence:
The Nile is the longest river in the world with a length of approximately 6650 km.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Gold is m̲u̲c̲h̲ costly than any other metal.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.37_23-Oct_Shift-2)
solution:
Answer:more

Explanation:
The word "much" is incorrectly used with the adjective "costly" in a comparative context.
The correct comparative form is "more costly" – meaning more expensive (अधिक महंगा).

Let’s evaluate the options:

  • most costlier – incorrect because it’s a double superlative (most + -er) → ❌

  • many – grammatically incorrect here → ❌

  • most – superlative, but the sentence is making a comparison, not identifying the top one → ❌

  • more – correct comparative form: more costly than → ✅

Correct sentence:
Gold is more costly than any other metal.

question:
Select the correct option of the given sentence.
Vishnu is the more courageous than all other boys in the class.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.38_23-Oct_Shift-3)
option_1: Vishnu is more courageous than all other boys in the class.
option_2: Vishnu is much more courageous than all other boys in the class.
option_3: Vishnu is most courageous than all other boys in the class.
option_4: Vishnu is the most courageous than all other boys in the class.
solution:
Answer:Vishnu is more courageous than all other boys in the class.

Explanation:
The sentence compares Vishnu with all other boys, so the use of the comparative degree (more courageous) is correct.

However, the original sentence incorrectly uses "the more courageous", which is unnecessary and ungrammatical with "than all other boys".

Let’s review the options:

  • Vishnu is more courageous than all other boys in the class. → ✅ Correct comparative structure

  • Vishnu is much more courageous... → ❌ "Much more" is unnecessary here

  • Vishnu is most courageous than... → ❌ "Most" is superlative, but "than" requires comparative

  • Vishnu is the most courageous than... → ❌ Incorrect mix of superlative and comparative

Correct sentence:
Vishnu is more courageous than all other boys in the class.

question:
Select the most appropriate form of comparative degree that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Food prices in Switzerland are e̲x̲p̲e̲n̲s̲i̲v̲e̲r̲ ̲t̲o̲ the rest of Western Europe.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.38_23-Oct_Shift-3)
solution:
Answer:more expensive than

Explanation:
The word "expensiver" is incorrect because "expensive" is a multi-syllable adjective that forms its comparative degree with "more", not by adding "-er".

Also, when comparing two things, we use "than", not "to".

Let’s evaluate the options:

  • more expensive than – ✅ Correct comparative form and correct preposition

  • as expensiver to – ❌ "Expensiver" is wrong; "as...to" is incorrect usage

  • the most expensive than – ❌ "Most" is superlative; "than" doesn’t follow it

  • more expensive to – ❌ "To" is incorrect preposition; should be "than"

Correct sentence:
Food prices in Switzerland are more expensive than the rest of Western Europe.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Wolves’ teeth are larger and s̲t̲r̲o̲n̲g̲ than dog’s teeth.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.39_28-Oct_Shift-1)
solution:
Answer:stronger

Explanation:
The sentence compares wolves’ teeth with dog’s teeth, so we need the comparative degree of the adjective "strong".

Let’s evaluate the options:

  • the stronger – superlative article "the" is incorrect in a two-part comparison → ❌

  • stronger – correct comparative form of "strong" → ✅

  • more strong – incorrect; "strong" takes "-er", not "more" → ❌

  • strongest – superlative form, used when comparing more than two → ❌

Correct sentence:
Wolves’ teeth are larger and stronger than dog’s teeth.

question:
Select the appropriate option that can substitute the underlined word in the following sentence to make it grammatically correct.
The grapes taste s̲w̲e̲e̲t̲e̲s̲t̲.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.40_28-Oct_Shift-2)
solution:
Answer:sweet

Explanation:
The verb "taste" here is a linking verb, and linking verbs are followed by an adjective, not a comparative or superlative form, unless comparison is clearly stated.

In this sentence, there is no comparison being made, so the correct form is just the base adjective "sweet" – मीठा.

Let’s examine the options:

  • more sweeter – ❌ incorrect (double comparative)

  • sweet – ✅ correct (simple adjective)

  • sweeter – ❌ comparative, but no comparison is present

  • most sweeter – ❌ double superlative; grammatically wrong

Correct sentence:
The grapes taste sweet.

question:
Select the appropriate option that can substitute the underlined word in the following sentence to make it grammatically correct.
Meerut is f̲a̲r̲t̲h̲e̲s̲t̲ from Delhi.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.43_29-Oct_Shift-2)
solution:
Answer:far

Explanation:
The original sentence is:
"Meerut is farthest from Delhi."

This is incorrect because “farthest” is a superlative form, which is used only when comparing more than two things or places. In this sentence, only two places (Meerut and Delhi) are mentioned, and no comparison is being made.

We are simply stating the distance between the two. In such cases, we use the base form "far".

Let’s understand the other options:

  • far – ✅ Correct when stating general distance without comparison

  • farther – comparative form; used when comparing two places

  • farthest – superlative; used for more than two → ❌

  • more farther / most farthest – grammatically incorrect (double comparative/superlative) → ❌

Correct sentence:
"Meerut is far from Delhi."

This is grammatically correct and appropriately structured for the context.

question:
Change the following into superlative degree.
She is taller than other girls in the class.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.43_29-Oct_Shift-2)
option_1: She is tall girl in the class.
option_2: She is the tallest girl in the class.
option_3: In the class she is taller than other girls.
option_4: No other girl in the class is as tall as she.
solution:
Answer:She is the tallest girl in the class.

Explanation:
The original sentence is:
"She is taller than other girls in the class."

This is a comparative sentence (using "taller than") comparing one person with others. To convert it into the superlative degree, we must use:

👉 "the + superlative adjective + noun + in..."

So, the correct transformation is:
"She is the tallest girl in the class."

Let’s review the options:

  • She is tall girl in the class. → ❌ Missing article "a" or "the", and not superlative

  • She is the tallest girl in the class. → ✅ Correct superlative form

  • In the class she is taller than other girls. → ❌ Still comparative, not superlative

  • No other girl in the class is as tall as she. → ❌ Positive degree, not superlative

Thus, the correct superlative version is:
"She is the tallest girl in the class."

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
This is the o̲l̲d̲ tree in the colony.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.44_29-Oct_Shift-3)
solution:
Answer:oldest

Explanation:
The sentence is:
"This is the old tree in the colony."

We are referring to one specific tree that is the oldest among all others in the colony. So, we need the superlative form of the adjective "old".

Let’s examine the options:

  • most old – ❌ Incorrect formation; "old" takes the -est form, not "most"

  • oldest – ✅ Superlative form of "old"; correct for comparing one with all others

  • elder – ❌ Used for people (e.g., elder brother), not things like trees

  • older – ❌ Comparative form (used when comparing two), not superlative

Correct sentence:
This is the oldest tree in the colony.

oldest – superlative form of “old” → सबसे पुराना (Hindi meaning)

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
This is the c̲h̲e̲a̲p̲ saree in my collection.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.44_29-Oct_Shift-3)
solution:
Answer:cheapest

Explanation:
The sentence is:
"This is the cheap saree in my collection."

We are referring to one saree that is the lowest in price among all sarees in the collection. So, we need the superlative form of "cheap", which is "cheapest".

Let’s evaluate the options:

  • cheaper – ❌ Comparative form; used when comparing two items

  • more cheap – ❌ Incorrect; "cheap" takes "-er" or "-est" forms, not "more"

  • most cheapest – ❌ Incorrect; double superlative (most + -est)

  • cheapest – ✅ Correct superlative form

Correct sentence:
This is the cheapest saree in my collection.

cheapest – superlative form of “cheap” → सबसे सस्ती (Hindi meaning)

question:
Select the appropriate option that can substitute the underlined word in the following sentence to make it grammatically correct.
This novel is m̲o̲r̲e̲ ̲i̲n̲t̲e̲r̲e̲s̲t̲i̲n̲g̲ of all in the library.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.44_29-Oct_Shift-3)
solution:
Answer:the most interesting

Explanation:
The sentence is:
"This novel is more interesting of all in the library."

We are comparing one novel with all others in the library. In such cases, we use the superlative form with "the".

  • more interesting – comparative form (used when comparing two) → ❌

  • most interesting – superlative, but missing "the" → ❌

  • the more interesting – incorrect because it's not a complete superlative → ❌

  • the most interesting – ✅ correct superlative form used when comparing one with all others

Correct sentence:
This novel is the most interesting of all in the library.

the most interesting – सबसे अधिक रोचक (Hindi meaning)
